Situation1: A winter storm is slowing traffic while the passenger must catch an international flight
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: Tax documents are organized a month before the deadline, and a free vaccine clinic runs this weekend at the community center.
Story:
The snow was coming down hard, swirling in thick sheets across the windshield as I gripped the steering wheel. My passenger, a nervous businessman, kept glancing at his watch and muttering about missing his flight. As a taxi driver, I knew he expected me to get him to the airport on time, no matter the weather. But the roads were slick, and every minute I spent driving faster than I should was a risk—not just to us, but to everyone else on the road. 

At the same time, as a citizen, I’d promised myself I’d get my taxes done early this year, and the vaccine clinic at the community center was this weekend. I wanted to set a good example, to do my part for public health and civic responsibility. But right now, all I could think about was the pressure to speed up, to ignore the rules for the sake of my passenger’s schedule. My hands tightened on the wheel as I wrestled with what was right—for him, for me, and for everyone else out there in the storm.
